content.title: Diabetes Mellitus Type 1
content.summary: Autoimmune destruction of pancreatic beta cells leading to absolute insulin deficiency requiring lifelong exogenous insulin therapy
key_points: Autoimmune T-cell mediated destruction of pancreatic beta cells
Absolute insulin deficiency requiring exogenous insulin
Typically presents in childhood or adolescence but can occur at any age
Associated with other autoimmune conditions (thyroiditis, celiac disease)
C-peptide levels are low or undetectable
GAD65, IA-2, and ZnT8 autoantibodies are diagnostic markers
content.statement: Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus (T1DM) is a chronic autoimmune metabolic disorder characterized by selective destruction of insulin-producing pancreatic beta cells, resulting in absolute insulin deficiency and hyperglycemia requiring lifelong insulin replacement therapy.

explanation.intuition: Imagine the pancreas as a factory producing insulin, the key that unlocks cells to allow glucose entry. In T1DM, the immune system mistakenly attacks and destroys this factory, eliminating insulin production entirely.
explanation.key_insight: Unlike Type 2 diabetes where insulin resistance is primary, T1DM involves complete loss of insulin production. This distinction is crucial because T1DM patients are absolutely dependent on exogenous insulin for survival.
explanation.technical_details: T1DM pathogenesis involves genetic susceptibility (HLA-DR3/DR4), environmental triggers (viral infections, dietary factors), and autoimmune mechanisms. Beta cell destruction is mediated primarily by CD8+ cytotoxic T lymphocytes recognizing beta cell autoantigens (proinsulin, GAD65, IA-2, ZnT8). Clinical diabetes manifests when 80-90% of beta cells are destroyed.

definitions_glossary.autoimmune_disease: A condition where the immune system mistakenly attacks the body's own tissues
definitions_glossary.beta_cells: Insulin-producing cells located in the islets of Langerhans within the pancreas
definitions_glossary.insulin: A peptide hormone produced by beta cells essential for glucose uptake into cells
definitions_glossary.c_peptide: A byproduct of insulin production used to assess endogenous insulin secretion
definitions_glossary.diabetic_ketoacidosis: A life-threatening complication caused by insulin deficiency leading to hyperglycemia, ketosis, and acidosis
definitions_glossary.hla_complex: Human leukocyte antigen genes that regulate immune response and confer genetic susceptibility to T1DM
definitions_glossary.gad65_antibody: Glutamic acid decarboxylase-65 autoantibody, a diagnostic marker for autoimmune diabetes
definitions_glossary.ia2_antibody: Islet antigen-2 autoantibody associated with beta cell autoimmunity
definitions_glossary.znt8_antibody: Zinc transporter 8 autoantibody, highly specific for T1DM
definitions_glossary.honeymoon_period: Transient phase after diagnosis where residual beta cell function allows reduced insulin requirements
definitions_glossary.basal_bolus_regimen: Insulin therapy mimicking physiologic secretion with long-acting basal and rapid-acting meal-time insulin
definitions_glossary.continuous_glucose_monitoring: Device that continuously measures interstitial glucose levels providing real-time data

pathophysiology.mechanism: Autoimmune T-cell mediated destruction of pancreatic beta cells in genetically susceptible individuals triggered by environmental factors
genetic_factors: HLA-DR3 and HLA-DR4 haplotypes confer highest risk
Multiple non-HLA genes contribute (INS, PTPN22, CTLA4, IL2RA)
immunological_cascade: Initial sensitization to beta cell antigens
Activation of autoreactive CD4+ and CD8+ T cells
Progressive insulitis with beta cell apoptosis
Clinical diabetes when >80-90% beta cells destroyed

clinical_presentation: Polyuria, polydipsia, polyphagia, weight loss (classic triad)
laboratory_criteria: Random plasma glucose ≥200 mg/dL with symptoms
autoantibody_testing: Insulin autoantibodies (IAA, more common in children)
diagnostic_criteria.c_peptide_assessment: Fasting C-peptide <0.2 nmol/L or stimulated <0.6 nmol/L indicates absolute insulin deficiency

regimens: Basal-bolus: Long-acting insulin (glargine, detemir, degludec) + rapid-acting at meals (lispro, aspart, glulisine)
dosing_principles: Basal insulin: 40-50% of total daily dose

glucose_monitoring: Continuous glucose monitoring (CGM) for real-time glucose trends
HbA1c every 3 months; target <7% for most adults
adjunctive_therapies: SGLT2 inhibitors as adjunct (with DKA precautions)
Islet cell transplantation for severe hypoglycemia unawareness

skos.definition: A chronic autoimmune metabolic disorder characterized by T-cell mediated destruction of pancreatic beta cells resulting in absolute insulin deficiency

subcodes: E10.10 - Type 1 diabetes mellitus with ketoacidosis without coma
E10.65 - Type 1 diabetes mellitus with hyperglycemia

learning_objectives: Describe the autoimmune pathophysiology underlying T1DM beta cell destruction
Differentiate T1DM from T2DM based on clinical presentation and laboratory findings
Interpret autoantibody panels and C-peptide levels for T1DM diagnosis
Design appropriate basal-bolus insulin regimens for T1DM management
Recognize and manage acute complications including DKA and hypoglycemia
Counsel patients on carbohydrate counting and glucose monitoring
clinical_pearls: Always check for DKA at initial presentation - 30% of newly diagnosed T1DM presents with DKA
Honeymoon period can last weeks to months after diagnosis - don't discontinue insulin
GAD65 antibodies can remain positive for years while other antibodies wane
C-peptide distinguishes T1DM from T2DM in cases of diagnostic uncertainty
Screen annually for thyroid disease and celiac disease due to autoimmune clustering
Consider LADA (Latent Autoimmune Diabetes of Adults) in adults initially diagnosed with T2DM who fail oral agents
Hypoglycemia unawareness develops after years of tight control - liberalize targets if present

step3_concepts: Transition of care from pediatric to adult
common_questions: Young patient with polyuria/polydipsia and weight loss - next step?
Distinguishing features between T1DM and T2DM

clinical_pearls: Absolute insulin deficiency distinguishes T1DM from T2DM
GAD65, IA-2, and ZnT8 autoantibodies confirm autoimmune etiology
C-peptide <0.2 nmol/L indicates complete beta cell failure
DKA can be the presenting manifestation in 30% of cases
Screen for autoimmune thyroiditis and celiac disease annually
